text: this is an impressive haul for tons of
ivory with a market value of around 6
million dollars
it was probably destined to be fashioned
into objects for the Chinese market we
tracked this shipment for two months to
customs director-general Somchai Suja
pon we were told the ivory would come
from Africa and be smuggled out of
Thailand through Laos but does this
signify a tougher Thais stance towards
this lucrative business two years ago
then Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra
promised a crackdown and Thailand was
given until the end of last month to
produce a credible action plan to end
the trade the government says it's now
done this and it's passed a new law at
the Facebook page of this famous ivory
shop in nakhon sawan states that he's
now had to remove all photos of his
ivory products all ivory in Thailand
should now be subject to rigorous
inspection and registration Thailand has
long been an important link in the trade
between poachers in Africa and rising
demand for ivory in China but the threat
of sanctions under the site ease
agreement on endangered species
appears to have go to the Thai
authorities into action that could now
help to halt the slaughter of African
elephants but only if notoriously weak
law enforcement here is strengthened not
just now but for the long term to
Jonathan head BBC News Bangkok
